sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Complication of procedure - Hysteroscopy - Uterine distension: (intrauterine with hysteroscopy) instill through hysteroscope cannula under low pressure (approximately 100 mm Hg) but enough to keep cavity suitably distended; do not exceed 150 mm Hg to avoid injection of fluid into tissues or leaking into the peritoneal cavity
  • Dextran adverse reaction; Prophylaxis: Note: Promit(R) (dextran 1) is no longer available in the U.S.: 20 mL IV rapid infusion 1 to 2 min before the IV infusion of clinical dextran solutions
  • Extracorporeal circulation procedure, Pump primer; Adjunct: dose varies with volume of pump oxygenator; generally, LMD 10% solution (1 to 2 g) 10 to 20 mL/kg body weight; MAX total dose not to exceed 2 g/kg of body weight
  • Plasma expander transfusion; Adjunct - Traumatic shock: 10% dextran 40, initial dose 10 mL/kg IV, infused as rapidly as necessary to effect improvement, MAX dose 20 mL/kg in first 24 h; beyond 24 h, daily dose should not exceed 10 mL/kg/day, therapy should not exceed 5 days
  • Thromboembolic disorder, In procedures with high incidence of thromboembolic complications; Prophylaxis: 10% dextran 40, 500 to 1000 mL (10 mL/kg of body weight) IV on day of surgery, then 500 mL daily for 2 to 3 days; depending on risk of complications, may give 500 mL every second or third day during period of risk for up to 2 wks

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• Extracorporeal circulation procedure, Pump primer; Adjunct: infants, 10% dextran 40, 5 mL/kg of body weight IV
  • Extracorporeal circulation procedure, Pump primer; Adjunct: adolescents, dose varies with volume of pump oxygenator; generally, LMD 10% solution (1 to 2 g) 10 to 20 mL/kg body weight; MAX total dose not to exceed 2 g/kg of body weight
  • Plasma expander transfusion; Adjunct - Traumatic shock: infants, 10% dextran 40, 5 mL/kg of body weight IV
  • Plasma expander transfusion; Adjunct - Traumatic shock: adolescents, 10% dextran 40, initial dose 10 mL/kg IV, infused as rapidly as necessary to effect improvement, MAX 20 mL/kg in first 24 hr; beyond 24 hr, MAX 10 mL/kg/day, for no more than 5 days
  • Plasma expander transfusion; Adjunct - Traumatic shock: 6% dextran 70, up to 20 mL/kg
  • Thromboembolic disorder, In procedures with high incidence of thromboembolic complications; Prophylaxis: adolescents, 10% dextran 40, 500 to 1000 mL (10 mL/kg of body weight) IV on day of surgery, then 500 mL daily for 2 to 3 days; depending on risk of complications, may give 500 mL every second or third day during period of risk for up to 2 wks
  • Thromboembolic disorder, In procedures with high incidence of thromboembolic complications; Prophylaxis: infants, 10% dextran 40, 5 mL/kg of body weight IV

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Complication of procedure - Hysteroscopy - Uterine distension
  • Dextran adverse reaction; Prophylaxis
  • Extracorporeal circulation procedure, Pump primer; Adjunct
  • Plasma expander transfusion; Adjunct - Traumatic shock
  • Thromboembolic disorder, In procedures with high incidence of thromboembolic complications; Prophylaxis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Transplant of lung, Lung preservation

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to dextran or corn products
  • pulmonary edema
  • renal disease with severe oliguria or anuria
  • severe bleeding disorders
  • severe congestive heart failure

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• bowel surgery
  • decreased urinary output secondary to shock
  • dehydration
  • hemorrhage, active
  • hypernatremia (with products containing sodium chloride)
  • pathological abdominal conditions
  • thrombocytopenia

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• Intrauterine
    • (intrauterine with hysteroscopy) instill through hysteroscope cannula under low pressure (approximately 100 mm Hg) but enough to keep cavity suitably distended; do not exceed 150 mm Hg to avoid injection of fluid into tissues or leaking into the peritoneal cavity
    • heat at 100 to 110 degrees C if crystallization flakes are present (until complete dissolution)
  • Intravenous
    • (Dextran 40) give IV infusion only
    • (Dextran 40) prediluted in 500 mL of NS or D5; when infusing concentrated solution, use a filter

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• central venous pressure during initial infusion
  • observe for bleeding complications
  • urine output
  • hysteroscopy: signs of pulmonary edema, intravascular volume expansion (especially if procedure time > 45 min)

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono: Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of bleeding complications, pulmonary edema, congestive heart failure, or renal failure.
